Trial_Design.evidence: Patients between 18 and 60 years of age with an acute anterior shoulder dislocation were randomly allocated into 2 groups.

Participants.evidence: The study was carried out at the emergency department of a tertiary referral center. Patients between 18 and 60 years of age with an acute anterior shoulder dislocation.

Intervention.evidence: In 1 group the emergency doctor actively guided the reduction process with the Spaso technique (Sp group), and in the other group the patient used the Boss-Holzach-Matter (also known as Davos or Aronen) self-reduction technique (BHM group).

Objective.evidence: The objective of this study was to compare the pain experienced by a patient performing a self-reduction technique with the pain felt during a reduction performed by a trained physician.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The pain experienced by the patient during the reduction was recorded by means of a visual analogue scale (VAS) ranging from 0 to 10.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients between 18 and 60 years of age with an acute anterior shoulder dislocation were randomly allocated into 2 groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty acute anterior shoulder dislocations were randomized into the Sp group (n = 30) or the BHM group (n = 30).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Sixty acute anterior shoulder dislocations were randomized into the Sp group (n = 30) or the BHM group (n = 30).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The BHM group experienced significantly less pain during reduction than the Sp group (p = 0.047), with mean pain scores of 3.57 (standard deviation [SD] = 2.1]) and 5.26 (SD = 2.9), respectively.
